summary: This is a privilege log from a civil case (9:08-cv-80736-KAM) filed in Florida, listing documents withheld from discovery. It catalogs extensive investigative materials from 'Operation Leap Year,' including grand jury subpoenas, search warrants, financial records, flight manifests, victim/witness information, and attorney work product related to the Jeffrey Epstein investigation and potential indictment. This document is a privilege log from a court filing (Document 212-1) in case 9:08-cv-80736-KAM, detailing the contents of boxes of evidence related to the Jeffrey Epstein investigation. It lists numerous folders containing grand jury materials, draft indictments, victim analyses, legal research, correspondence, and internal memoranda, with assertions of various privileges (work product, 6(e), investigative, deliberative process, attorney-client). The log reveals the extensive scope of the federal investigation, codenamed 'Operation Leap Year,' and references key documents like the Non-Prosecution Agreement and immunity requests. This document is a privilege log from a court filing (likely a motion to compel or similar discovery dispute) listing documents withheld from production in the Jeffrey Epstein case. It details emails and letters between Department of Justice officials from 2008-2011 concerning the recusal of the entire U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida from the Epstein investigation, with attorney-client and deliberative process privileges asserted.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central subject of the federal investigation 'Operation Leap Year.' The document references draft indictments, a motion to quash subpoenas filed on his behalf, and a Non-Prosecution Agreement.

persons.name: Kenneth Starr
persons.context: Mentioned as the author of a November 28, 2007 letter found in research files, indicating his involvement in the legal proceedings surrounding the case.

persons.name: Acosta
persons.context: Referenced in the description of the 'Acosta-Sanchez Ltr' from December 19, 2007, which is a key document related to the Non-Prosecution Agreement.

persons.name: Sanchez
persons.context: Referenced alongside Acosta in the description of the 'Acosta-Sanchez Ltr' from December 19, 2007.

persons.name: Wifredo Ferrer
persons.role: U.S. Attorney, Southern District of Florida
persons.context: Recipient of a letter and emails regarding the formal notice of office-wide recusal of the Southern District of Florida from the Epstein investigation.

persons.name: Robert O'Neill
persons.role: U.S. Attorney, Middle District of Florida
persons.context: Recipient of an email regarding the formal notice of office-wide recusal of the Southern District of Florida.

connections.description: A letter from Kenneth Starr is found in the prosecution's research files, strongly suggesting Starr was providing legal counsel or representation to Epstein during the investigation.
Both are U.S. Attorneys (for different districts) copied on the same official DOJ email regarding the recusal of the Southern District of Florida.

events.title: FBI Interviews of New York Witness/Victim
events.description: FBI reports from March 2008 interviews of an additional witness/victim located in New York are listed in the privilege log.

events.title: FBI Interview Report
events.description: An FBI interview report from May 2008 is listed in a file folder bearing a victim's name, along with telephone activity reports and grand jury material.

events.title: Non-Prosecution Agreement Signed
events.description: Execution of the Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) between Jeffrey Epstein and the U.S. Attorney's Office, a central document in the case.

events.title: Complete Indictment Package Dated
events.description: A complete federal indictment package against Jeffrey Epstein was prepared by prosecutors.

events.title: Signed Indictment Dated
events.description: A later, signed indictment package was prepared, dated June 9, 2009, indicating ongoing indictment preparation efforts.

events.title: Kenneth Starr Letter
events.description: Kenneth Starr sends a letter, found in prosecution files, related to the case.

events.title: OPR Self-Reporting
events.description: Internal memos and letters from April 2008 to the DOJ's Office of Professional Responsibility regarding self-reporting and an allegation of a conflict of interest.

events.title: Self-Reporting Letter to OPR
events.description: A letter was sent to the Privacy Act Office of Professional Responsibility regarding self-reporting, with attachments.

events.title: SDFL Seeks Advice on Office-Wide Recusal
events.description: Emails between the Executive Office for U.S. Attorneys and the Southern District of Florida seeking advice regarding an office-wide recusal, with an attached letter to Wifredo A. Ferrer.

events.title: Emails on Recusal Matter
events.description: Emails between Assistant General Counsel and the First Assistant U.S. Attorney regarding a recusal matter.

events.title: Emails with Epstein Investigation Summary
events.description: Emails regarding the recusal of the Southern District of Florida, with an attached memorandum summarizing the Jeffrey Epstein investigation.

events.title: Formal Notice of Office-Wide Recusal
events.description: Formal notice was issued regarding the office-wide recusal of the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida from the Epstein matter. This was communicated via email to U.S. Attorneys Ferrer and O'Neill.

keyFacts: The document is a detailed privilege log from a 2013 civil case, cataloging materials from 'Operation Leap Year,' the federal investigation into Jeffrey Epstein.

The withheld materials are extensive and include grand jury subpoena logs (OLY-01 through OLY-81), sealed search warrant applications, financial records from banks (Colonial, JP Morgan Chase, Washington Mutual), flight manifests, and victim/witness meta-analysis charts.

Specific folders indicate the compilation of evidence for indictment preparation, including charts summarizing sexual activity, telephone calls, and travel for numerous victims identified as 'Jane Does #1-19' and others.
The log references FBI interview reports from March and May 2008, police reports, and correspondence regarding witness immunity requests, showing the depth of the prior investigation.
Privileges asserted include Federal Rule of Criminal Procedure 6(e) (grand jury secrecy), work product, attorney-client privilege, investigative privilege, and protections for victim privacy.
The federal investigation was codenamed 'Operation Leap Year' and involved extensive grand jury proceedings, victim analysis, and legal research spanning from 2007 to 2009.

Prosecutors compiled detailed 'meta-analysis' folders for at least 13 Jane Doe victims (#'s 1-14, with some gaps), analyzing their phone records, travel data, and grand jury information for indictment preparation.
The privilege log references the controversial 'Non-Prosecution Agreement' dated December 19, 2007, and associated 'Acosta-Sanchez' letter, which were central to the later litigation.
The document shows prosecutors were actively researching a wide range of potential federal charges against Epstein, including Mann Act violations, money laundering, and Travel Act offenses.
Multiple names of individuals (victims, attorneys, officials) are redacted or referred to by title (e.g., 'AUSA', 'case agent') in the log, indicating the sensitivity of the information.
The entire U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida was formally recused from the Jeffrey Epstein investigation by August 2011.

The recusal process involved high-level DOJ officials, including the Executive Office for United States Attorneys, and was a subject of internal deliberation and legal advice starting as early as December 2010.
A memorandum summarizing the Jeffrey Epstein investigation was attached to emails about the recusal dated July 29, 2011.
The document is a privilege log, indicating these communications about the recusal were withheld from discovery in litigation, asserting attorney-client and deliberative process privileges.
The log reveals coordination between the Southern District of Florida and the Middle District of Florida (U.S. Attorney Robert O'Neill) regarding the recusal notice.
